[SYNTAX]: Cumbersome sentence structure in "The prophet or pioneer... antiquated" disrupts flow.
Awkward phrasing in "The German Von Eicken found... master key of history" creates confusion.
Cumbersome parallel structure in "The Catholic Church began by renouncing... became the heir..."
[LEXICON]: Overuse of archaic terms ("to-day," "saeculum mirabile") may hinder readability.
[SPELLING]: "Waggon" (British spelling) is inconsistent with modern standard "wagon."

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from industrial revolution to pre-industrial England without clear connective tissue.
[LOGIC]: Sudden example of "Dean Colet" feels disconnected from broader population discussion.
Jump from national isolation to German inspiration lacks transitional explanation.
[STRUCTURE]: Unclear link between French Revolution panic and delayed democratic reforms.
[CLARITY]: Vague reference to "the most hated rival" without prior context.

[GRAMMAR]: Misplaced modifier in "We however who have witnessed..."
[SYNTAX]: Long and complex sentence about the double effect on rural labourers
Awkward construction in "The country was, in vulgar language..."
[SPELLING]: "waggon-loads" appears to be a spelling error
[PUNCTUATION]: Missing appropriate punctuation between independent clauses

[LOGIC]: Abrupt shifts between topics (war impact, working class, overpopulation, progress)
Unclear connections between economic conditions and social topics
Disconnected discussion of economic conditions and progress
[STRUCTURE]: Lack of clear transitions between different sections
Disjointed flow of ideas across multiple topics

Use of complex/archaic language in some passages
